abstract.text: 2 14 HIGHLIGHTS 15  Models of conserved 5' and 3' betacoronavirus cis-acting RNA secondary structures are 16 presented 17  The 5' cis-acting sequences required for coronavirus replication extend into the first open reading 18 frame 19  All 3' cis-acting sequences required for coronavirus replication are contained in the 3'UTR 20  A putative molecular switch is present in the coronavirus 3'UTR 21  Proteins interacting with these cis-acting regions are reviewed 22 23 24 25 ABSTRACT 26 Coronaviruses (CoVs) are an important cause of illness in humans and animals. Most human 27 coronaviruses commonly cause relatively mild respiratory illnesses; however two zoonotic 28 coronaviruses, SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, can cause severe illness and death. Investigations 29 over the past thirty-five years have illuminated many aspects of coronavirus replication. The 30 focus of this review is the functional analysis of conserved RNA secondary structures in the 5' 31 and 3' of the betacoronavirus genomes. The 5' 350 nucleotides folds into a set of RNA 32 secondary structures which are well conserved, and reverse genetic studies indicate that these 33 structures play an important role in the discontinuous synthesis of subgenomic RNAs in the 34 betacoronaviruses. These cis-acting elements extend 3' of the 5'UTR into ORF1a. The 3'UTR 35 is similarly conserved and contains all of the cis-acting sequences necessary for viral replication. 36 Two competing conformations near the 5' end of the 3'UTR have been shown to make up a 37 Page 3 of 50 3 potential molecular switch. There is some evidence that an association between the 3' and 38 5'UTRs is necessary for subgenomic RNA synthesis, but the basis for this association is not yet 39 clear. A number of host RNA proteins have been shown to bind to the 5' and 3' cis-acting 40 regions, but the significance of these in viral replication is not clear. Two viral proteins have 41 been identified as binding to the 5' cis-acting region, nsp1 and N protein. A genetic interaction 42 between nsp8 and nsp9 and the region of the 3'UTR that contains the putative molecular switch 43 suggests that these two proteins bind to this region. 44 45 Page 4 of 50 4 HIGHLIGHTS 45  Models of conserved 5' and 3' betacoronavirus cis-acting RNA secondary structures are 46 presented 47  The 5' cis-acting sequences required for coronavirus replication extend into the first open reading 48 frame 49  All 3' cis-acting sequences required for coronavirus replication are contained in the 3'UTR 50  A putative molecular switch is present in the coronavirus 3'UTR 51  Proteins interacting with these cis-acting regions are reviewed 52 53

Gammacoronaviruses include avian coronavirus and whale coronavirus SW1. 76 coronavirus TRSs include conserved 6-8 nucleotides core sequence (CS) plus variable 5' and 3' 123 flanking sequences (Sola et al., 2005) . Betacoronaviruses contain a consensus heptameric 124 sequence, 5'-UCUAAAC-3', with the SARS-CoV TRS having 5'-ACGAAC-3' as the core 125 sequence (Marra et al., 2003; Rota et al., 2003) . Replication occurs shortly after entry and 126 uncoating of the virion through production of full-length genomic and subgenomic negative 127 strand intermediates Sawicki and Sawicki, 1990; Sethna et al., 1989) . vesicles which eventually fuse with the plasma membrane to release virus into the extracellular 141 space (Holmes, 1996) . 142

Coronavirus messenger RNA 1, which is genome length, containing two overlapping 144 reading frames ORF 1a and 1b, directs the synthesis of two precursor polyproteins pp1a and 145 pp1ab, via a -1 frameshifting mechanism involving a pseudoknot structure (Bredenbeek et al., 146 1990 ). The polyproteins are then processed by two or three virus-encoded (in ORF1a) proteinase 147 domains to produce a membrane-bound replicase-transcriptase complex (Brockway et al., 2003) . 148

body_text.text: Upon proteolytic processing, the frameshifted ORF 1ab polypeptide generates 15-16 149 nonstructural proteins, many of which are involved in either RNA synthesis or proteolytic 150 processing required for viral replication: nsp1-nsp11 encoded in ORF 1a and nsp12-16 encoded 151 in ORF1b (Ziebuhr et al., 2000) . ORF 1a encodes three protease domains, one or two papain-like 152 domains in nsp3 depending on the particular coronavirus, and one picornavirus 3C-like domain 153 in nsp5 (Schiller et al., 1998; Weiss et al., 1994) . Nsp8 in ORF 1a contains a second RNA-154 dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) domain that is proposed to function as a primase and 155 produce primers utilized by the primer-dependent nsp12 RdRp (Imbert et al., 2006) . to the specific receptor on host cell plasma membranes. S is a class I fusion protein inducing cell 167 fusion. In some betacoronaviruses and all gammacoronaviruses, the precursor polypeptide is cleaved by a cellular protease into noncovalently associated amino-terminal S1 and carboxy-169 terminal S2 subunits. The receptor binding domain (RBD) of MHV S1 determines receptor 170 specificity, and S2 contains the transmembrane domain and two heptad repeat regions (HR1 and 171 HR2) required for fusion activity (McRoy and Baric, 2008

body_text.text: Viral RNA synthesis occurs in the cytoplasm on double-walled membrane vesicles 191 (Gosert et al., 2002; Knoops et al., 2008) . During MHV RNA replication and transcription of 192 subgenomic RNAs, the genomic RNA serves as a template for the synthesis of full-length and 193 subgenomic negative-strand RNAs, the latter through a discontinuous transcription mechanism 194 (Sawicki and Sawicki, 1990; Sawicki and Sawicki, 1998; Sola et al., 2005; van Marle et al., 195 1999; Zuniga et al., 2004) . In turn, full-length negative-strand RNAs serve as templates for the replication. Several studies showed that approximately 400 nts to 800 nts at the 5' end and 400 226 nts at the 3' end of MHV RNA genome are necessary for DI RNA replication (Kim et al., 1993; 227 Lin and Lai, 1993; Luytjes et al., 1996) . The minimal length of 5' sequence that supported MHV 228 DI replication is 467 nts (Luytjes et al., 1996) BCoV and SARS-CoV, containing conserved stem-loops SL1, SL2, SL4 and SL5ABC which 370 contains a four-helix junction in the models for all four viruses (Fig. 1) . One difference in the 371 MERS-CoV predicted structure is the presence of a short stem-loop located at positions 178-190 372 between SL4 and SL5ABC that is unlabeled in Fig. 1C . The functional significance of this stem-loop remains to be investigated. Both MERS-CoV and Bat CoV HKU5-1 have single-stranded 374 region between SL2 and SL4. 375

The coronavirus 3'UTR consists of 300 to 500 nts plus a poly(A) tail, depending upon the 547 particular coronavirus examined. Initial replication assays with MHV DI RNAs indicated that the 548 minimal length of 3' sequence required for MHV DI RNA replication was 436 nts, including part 549 of the N gene and the entire 3'UTR 301 nts (Lin and Lai, 1993; Luytjes et al., 1996) et al., 2002) . In a DI replication 557 assay the minimal cis-acting signal essential for negative-strand RNA synthesis was only the 3' 558 most 55 nts of the genome plus the poly(A) tail (Lin et al., 1994) . The poly(A) tail has been 559 identified as an important cis-acting signal required for BCoV DI RNA replication, although as 560 little as five As sufficed to initiate replication (Spagnolo and Hogue, 2000) . The poly(A) tail has 561 also been shown to be necessary for MHV minus-strand RNA synthesis (Lin et al., 1994) . Fig. 2 (Zust et al., 2008) . 567
body_text.section: 3' Cis-Acting RNA Elements in Coronavirus Replication and Transcription 546

body_text.text: The 5'-most secondary structure is a 68 nts bulged stem-loop just downstream of the N gene stop 568 codon, and it is essential for MHV DI RNA and viral replication (Hsue et al., 2000; Hsue and 569 Masters, 1997) . This bulged stem-loop is predicted to be conserved amongst the 570 betacoronaviruses and the pairing, but not the primary sequence, of the four covariant base pairs, 571 is critical for the function of the secondary structure (Goebel et al., 2004b; Hsue and Masters, 572 1997) . 3' to the 68 nts bulged stem-loop is a hairpin stem-loop which can form a 54 nts hairpin-573 type pseudoknot, which is required for BCoV DI RNA replication (Williams et al., 1999) . The 574 pseudoknot is phylogenetically conserved among coronaviruses, both in location and in shape 575 but only partially in nucleotide sequence, indicating that it may function as a regulatory control 576 element. Computer assisted inspection of the MERS-CoV sequence indicated it is present in this 577 newly recognized betacoronavirus as well, although in this virus the pseudoknot may contain a 578 non-canonical base pair (Fig. 2) . Goebel et al. (Goebel et al., 2004a) demonstrated that in MHV and BCoV, the bulged stem-loop and pseudoknot are in part mutually exclusive structures 580 because they partially overlap and cannot be formed simultaneously (see Fig. 2 ). The authors 581

body_text.text: proposed that the bulged stem-loop and pseudoknot are the components of a molecular switch 582 which has the potential to regulate a transition occurring during viral RNA synthesis, and 583 supported this hypothesis by a series of reverse genetic experiments (Goebel et al., 2004a) . performed a series of biophysical studies demonstrating that the pseudoknotted conformation is 597 much less stable than the double-hairpin conformation, but suggest that stacking of the 598 pseudoknot with the S3 helix can stabilize the pseudoknotted conformation allowing it to form. 599

body_text.text: Consistent with the biophysical studies, a reverse genetic study of this three helix junction region 600 suggested that S3 is essential for viral replication (Liu et al., 2013) . However, mutations 601 disrupting the S4 helix of the triple helix junction, or deleting most of the L3 loop are tolerated.

body_text.text: For the alphacoronaviruses, although the pseudoknot is conserved the bulged stem loop 603 (BSL in Fig. 2 ) that is 5' to the pseudoknot is absent (Dye and Siddell, 2005). In the 604 gammacoronaviruses a stem-loop located at the upstream end of the 3'UTR is required for viral 605 replication (Dalton et al., 2001) . Although a nearby pseudoknot is present in gammacoronavirus, 606 its functional importance has not been established (Williams et al., 1999) . Only in the 607 betacoronaviruses are both the pseudoknot and the bulged stem-loop closely overlapped. 608

body_text.text: Although the primary sequences diverge among the betacoronaviruses, the secondary structures A fair number of host proteins have been reported to interact with these cis-acting signals and 623 these are reviewed below. It should be noted that majority of this work has been performed with 624 they recognize are likely to be conserved, it is possible that there might be some differences 626 amongst the four coronavirus genera. 627 Two viral proteins have been shown to bind to the coronavirus 5'UTR, the N protein and 628 nsp1 ( Table 1) The MHV NTD forms a high affinity (K obs ≈8 x 10 7 M -1 ) 1:1 complex with a TRS-containing 643 RNA (5'-gAAUCUAAAC) and its complement (cTRS) (Grossoehme et al., 2009) . A recent 644 study showed that the NTD-TRS interaction involves N residues R125, Y127, and Y190 and 645 anchors the adenosine-rich region in the 3' end of the TRS RNA to the β-platform of N and that 646 this interaction is critical for efficient sgRNA synthesis (Keane et al., 2012) . This same study 647 also showed that the IBV and SARS-CoV N protein NTD shows limited binding specificity for their cognate TRS sequences (Keane et al., 2012) . Thus it is not clear that the specific binding of 649 N protein to the TRS over and above its general RNA binding activity plays a role in sgRNA 650 synthesis for all coronaviruses. The second viral protein that has been shown to bind to the 651 5'UTR is nsp1 (Gustin et al., 2009 ). The BCoV nsp1 protein has been determined to bind to 652 three cis-acting stem loops in the 5'UTR, including SLIII, which corresponds to SL4b in our 653 model and to regulate viral RNA translation and replication (Gustin et al., 2009) . It is likely that 654 the closely related MHV nsp1 protein has a similar function. 655 A number of host proteins have been shown to bind to the 5'UTR as well (Table 1) subgenomic RNAs, suggesting that hnRNP A1 is not required for MHV discontinuous 669 transcription or genome replication. However, it has been shown that multiple other type 670 hnRNPs, including hnRNP A2/B1, hnRNP A/B, and hnRNP A3, bind to the negative strand complement of the MHV leader TRS (Shi et al., 2003) and that overexpression of hnRNP A/B 672 resulted in a 4-5 fold enhancement of viral RNA synthesis, suggesting that these proteins might 673 also facilitate RNA synthesis and be able to substitute for hnRNP A1. Another member of the 674 hnRNP family, synaptotagmin-binding cytoplasmic RNA-interacting protein (SYNCRIP), 675 similarly binds to the MHV 5'UTR and to its negative strand complement (Choi et al., 2004) . 676
body_text.section: 3' Cis-Acting RNA Elements in Coronavirus Replication and Transcription 546

body_text.text: The L-TRS sequence has been shown to be necessary but sufficient for SYNCRIP binding and RNase protection/gel mobility shift and UV cross-linking assays and a conserved 11 nts UGAAUGAAGUU sequence spanning position 26-36 in the 3'UTR (note that in this 695 numbering system position 1 is the first nt upstream of the poly(A) tail) was necessary for 696 protein binding activity and for efficient DI RNA replication (Yu and Leibowitz, 1995a ; Yu and 697 Leibowitz, 1995b) . A second protein binding region was similarly mapped within a 38 698 nucleotide (nt) sequence 166-129 nucleotides upstream of the 3' end of the MHV genome and 699 was also found to be necessary for efficient DI RNA replication (Liu et al., 1997) . Subsequent 700 studies determined that the proteins binding to the MHV 3'-most 42 nts element include 701 mitochondrial aconitase and the chaperones mitochondrial HSP70, HSP60 and HSP40 (Nanda et 702 al., 2004; Nanda and Leibowitz, 2001) . PTB has been shown to bind to a negative-strand RNA 703 complementary to the MHV 3'UTR at position 53 to 149 and less strongly at positions 270-307 704 . Deletions in the 53-149 binding site that abolished PTB binding also 705 strongly inhibited subgenomic mRNA synthesis in an MHV DI construct containing a reporter 706 gene under the control of a TRS sequence . In addition to binding to the 707 5'UTR, hnRNP A1 has two binding sites in the MHV 3' UTR and these binding sites are 708 complementary to the PTB binding sites in the negative sense 3'UTR enumerated above (Huang 709 and Lai, 2001) . DI RNAs containing a mutated hnRNP A1-binding site had reduced RNA 710 transcription and replication activities. Using an RNA affinity -mass spectroscopy approach 711 during translation (Sonenberg, 1996; Sonenberg et al., 1978 ). An interaction between PTB bound 735 to leader (and body) TRS has also been postulated to play a role in coronavirus transcription by 736 mediating an interaction between the TRS and the 3'UTR by binding to hnRNP A 1 bound to its 737 protein binding sites in the 3' UTR (Lai, 1997; Lai, 1998) . Although this is an attractive model, 738 the fact that a deletion encompassing the high affinity hnRNP A1 binding site in the 3'UTR is 739 able to replicate and direct normal synthesis of subgenomic mRNAs makes the PTB-hnRNP A1 740 association less likely to have a crucial role in leader-body rejoining (Goebel et al., 2007) , 741 although the possibility that other members of the hnRNP family could substitute for hnRNP A1 742 remains a possibility (see section 5 for a discussion of this). Li et al. (Li et al., 2008) reported 743 that viruses recovered after deletion of a bulged A35 in the lower portion of the 5'UTR SL1 stem 744 contain additional second site mutations, A29G or A78G in the 3'UTR, providing genetic 745 evidence in support of an interaction between the 5' and 3'UTRs. They proposed a dynamic SL1 746 model in which the base of SL1 has an optimized lability required to mediate a physical 747 interaction between the 5'UTR and the 3'UTR that stimulates subgenomic RNA synthesis. In 748 unpublished work P. Liu and Leibowitz identified a potential base pairing between nucleotides 8-749 24 in the MHV 5' UTR SL1 and two discontinuous sequences in the 3'UTR, nts 1-6 and 218-228 750 (note that the 3'UTR sequences are numbered with position 1 corresponding to the first 751 nucleotide 5' of the poly (A) tail). An extensive mutational analysis of these sequences failed to 752 provide genetic support for a functional role for this potential 5'-3'UTR interaction in MHV 753 replication. Thus the precise mechanism by which the 5' and 3'UTRs associate during viral 754 replication remains to be functionally defined.

FIGREF0.text: The 5' cis-acting sequences required for coronavirus replication extend into the first open All 3' cis-acting sequences required for coronavirus replication are contained in the 3'UTR 20  A putative molecular switch is present in the coronavirus 3'UTR 21  Proteins interacting with these cis-acting regions are CoVs) are an important cause of illness in humans and animals. Most human 27 coronaviruses commonly cause relatively mild respiratory illnesses; however two zoonotic 28 coronaviruses, SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, can cause severe illness and death. Investigations 29 over the past thirty-five years have illuminated many aspects of coronavirus replication. The 30 focus of this review is the functional analysis of conserved RNA secondary structures in the 5' 31 and 3' of the betacoronavirus genomes. The 5' 350 nucleotides folds into a set of RNA 32 secondary structures which are well conserved, and reverse genetic studies indicate that these 33 structures play an important role in the discontinuous synthesis of subgenomic RNAs in the 34 betacoronaviruses. These cis-acting elements extend 3' of the 5'UTR into ORF1a. The 3'UTR 35

FIGREF1.text: The 5' cis-acting sequences required for coronavirus replication extend into the first All 3' cis-acting sequences required for coronavirus replication are contained in the 3'UTR50  A putative molecular switch is present in the coronavirus 3'UTR 51  Proteins interacting with these cis-acting regions are , SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, can cause severe illness and death. 57 Investigations over the past thirty-five years have illuminated many aspects of coronavirus 58 replication. The focus of this review is the structural and functional analyses of conserved ://ictvonline.org/virusTaxonomy.asp?version=2012), which together with Torovirinae make 64 up the Coronaviridae family in the order Nidovirales. The Coronavirinae are classified into four 65 genera Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, Deltacoronavirus and Gammacoronavirus. 66 Torovirinae includes two genera, Torovirus and Bafinivirus. The Coronaviridae comprises a 67 group of evolutionary related single-stranded, positive-sense, non-segmented, enveloped RNA 68 viruses of vertebrates. The RNA genomes are 25-31 kb, the largest genomes of all known RNA 69 viruses, and are infectious when introduced into permissive cells. However, unlike those of 70 almost all other positive-strand RNA viruses, the RNA infectivity of transfected coronavirus 71 genomes is greatly increased in the presence of a source of N protein (Casais et al., 2001; 72 Grossoehme et al., 2009; Yount et al., 2000). Alphacoronaviruses include alphacoronavirus 1 73 (transmissible gastroenteritis virus, TGEV), porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV), bat 74 coronavirus 1, BtCoV 512, BtCoV-HKU8, BtCoV-HKU2, human coronavirus HCoV-NL63 and 75

FIGREF2.text: 128 Translation of subgenomic mRNAs gives rise to structural and nonstructural viral proteins. The 129 replicated RNA genome is then encapsidated and packaged into virions. A minimal 69-nts 130 packaging signal has been characterized in MHV that maps within ORF1b approximately 20kb 131 from the 5' end of the genome, which is sufficient for RNA to be incorporated into virions 132 (Fosmire et al., 1992; Kuo and Masters, 2013; Makino et al., 1990; Narayanan et al., 2003; van 133 der Most et al., 1991). The BCoV packaging signal exhibits 74% sequence identity to the MHV 134 packaging signal and is located in a similar position (Cologna and Hogue, 2000). The TGEV 135 packaging signal was originally mapped to the first 649 nts at the 5' end of the genome; 136 subsequently this position was further delimited to the first 598 nts (Escors et al., 2003; Morales 137 et al., 2013). Viruses bud into smooth walled vesicles in the endoplasmic reticulum-Golgi 138 intermediate compartment (ERGIC). After budding, virus particles mature in the Golgi, with a 139 compact, electron-dense internal core. Viruses traverse the Golgi and are transported in exocytic 140

The enzymatic 162 activities of the exonuclease, endoribonuclease and S-adenosylmethionine-dependent 2′-O-163 methyl transferase encoded by nsp14, 15 and 16 are unique to Nidoviruses. Subgenomic mRNAs 164 encode the major viral structural proteins including spike proteins (S), envelope protein (E), 165 membrane protein (M), nucleocapsid protein (N), and the accessory proteins. FIGREF4.text: 196 synthesis of genome RNA and negative strand subgenomic RNAs serve as the templates for 197 subgenomic mRNA synthesis. In this discontinuous transcription model, negative-strand 198 subgenomic RNAs are transcribed from a genome-length template and leader-body joining is 199 accomplished during the synthesis of negative-strand subgenomic RNAs through a copy-choice 200 like mechanism involving TRS-B and TRS-L sequences (Pasternak et al., 2003; Sawicki and 201 Sawicki, 1990; Sawicki and Sawicki, 1998; van Marle et al., 1999; Zuniga et al., 2004). In an 202 elaboration of this model, viral and/or cellular factors binding to cis-acting RNA elements in the 203 genomic RNA 5' untranslated region (5'UTR) and 3'UTR, might circularize the genome, 204 promoting template switching by topologically enabling base pairing between TRS-L and the 205 nascent complementary TRS-Bs by the viral transcriptase/replicase complex (TRC) (Sola et al., 206 2005; Zuniga et al., 2004). Recently Mateos-Gomez et al. (Mateos-Gomez et al., 2013) 207 characterized a long-distance RNA-RNA interactions within the genomic RNA of TGEV, that 208 serves as a transcriptional enhancer by bringing the TRS-L and TRS-B controlling N gene 209 transcription into close proximity, raising the possibility that other similar long range RNA-RNA 210 interactions might be present in other abudently transcribed subgenomic RNAs. 211 The coronavirus RNA 5'UTR, the adjacent sequences encoding the amino-terminus of 213 nonstructural protein1 (nsp1) and the 3'UTR contain cis-acting sequences that fold into 214 secondary and higher-order structures, which contribute to their stability and to their 215 involvement in inter-and intra-molecular interactions. Those structures are functionally 216 important for RNA-RNA interactions and for the binding of viral and cellular proteins during 217 RNA replication and translation (Brian and Baric, 2005; Liu, 2010; Liu et al., 2009b) but cannot 218 be complemented in trans. Many cis-acting sequences and their functional roles in viral 219 transcription and replication were initially defined and studied in defective interfering (DI) 220 RNAs (Chang et al., 1994; Dalton et al., 2001; Kim and Makino, 1995; Liu et al., 2001; Makino 221 et al., 1985; Makino et al., 1988; Raman et al., 2003; Raman and Brian, 2005). These DI RNAs 222 are largely deleted but contain the cis-acting sequences necessary for their replication, including 223 the 5'UTR and 3'UTR. DI RNAs replicate by using the RNA synthesis machinery of helper 224 virus which provides replicase components in trans, and often interfere with viral genomic RNA 225

FIGREF5.text: ; the 3'UTR contains all the 3' cis-acting sequences 229 necessary for this process (de Haan et al., 2002; Goebel et al., 2004a). In BCoV the 5' 498 nts act 230 as a cis-acting signal for DI RNA replication (Chang et al., 1994). The development of reverse 231 genetic systems for a number of coronaviruses has allowed the study of cis-acting sequences and 232 their functions in the context of the whole viral genome. 233 MHV, BCoV and SARS-CoV are closely related in the Betacoronavirus genus 234 (Gorbalenya et al., 2006). The secondary structures in the 5'-end-proximal genomic regions of 235 these three viruses are largely conserved even though the nucleotide sequences are relatively 236 divergent (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010; Guan et al., 2012). A series of studies by consensus 237 covariation modeling, chemical probing, SHAPE technology, and nuclear magnetic resonance 238 (NMR) spectroscopy in conjunction with reverse genetics have been carried out, in order to 239 characterize the predicted secondary structures of cis-acting sequences in the 5'UTR and the N-240 terminal nsp1 coding region of MHV and BCoV and to identify their functional roles in viral 241 replication (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010; Guan et al., 2012; Guan et al., 2011; Li et al., 2008; Liu 242 et al., 2009a; Liu et al., 2007; Yang et al., 2011; Yang et al., 2015). 243 3. 1 Secondary Structure Models 244 The 5'-most 140 nts of the MHV genome have been predicted to contain three conserved 245 stem-loops (SL) 1, 2 and 4 based on a consensus secondary structural model from nine 246 representative coronaviruses using phylogenetic analysis, ViennaRNA, Mfold and PKNOTS 247 (Kang et al., 2006a; Liu et al., 2007). The nine coronaviruses modeled include five Beta-CoVs: 248 BCoV, human coronavirus HCoV-OC43, HKU1, SARS-CoV, MHV-A59; three Alpha-CoVs: 249 HCoV-NL63, HCoV-229E and TGEV; and one Gamma-CoV, IBV. The secondary structural 250 models of the 5' 140 nts of these coronaviruses are remarkably similar, and all contain three 251 conserved helical stems, SL1, SL2, and SL4. SARS-CoV and BCoV are also predicted to contain 252 an additional stem-loop, SL3, which folds the leader TRS (TRS-L) sequences into a hairpin loop. 253 For MHV, a similar base pairing scheme for SL3 can be drawn (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010), but 254 the SL3 stem is not predicted to be stable at 37ºC (Liu et al., 2007). The secondary structures of 255 the 5'UTR and adjacent coding sequences in all CoVs predicted by a structural-phylogenetic 256 analysis (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010) are largely consistent with the models by Kang et al. and 257 In a recent study (Yang et al., 2015), SHAPE technology was utilized to determine the 259 secondary structures formed by the 5' most 474 nts cis-acting region required for replication of 260 MHV-A59 DI RNA. The structure generated (Fig. 1A) was in excellent agreement with our 261 previous characterization of SL1 (Li et al., 2008), SL2 (Liu et al., 2009a; Liu et al., 2007) and the 262 correct structure for SL4 at position nts 80 to 130 (Yang et al., 2011). These stem-loops serve as 263 cis-acting elements required for driving subgenomic RNA synthesis. Interestingly, the stem 264 predicted for SL3 by phylogenetic algorithms (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010) in the TRS region was 265 single-stranded with relatively high SHAPE reactivity, consistent with the prediction of Liu et al. 266 (Liu et al., 2007) that this region was weakly paired or unpaired. The structure was also in good 267 agreement with the two recent models of MHV-A59 RNA secondary structure (Guan et al., 268 2012; Guan et al., 2011) that identified two additional cis-acting replication elements required 269 for optimal viral replication. S5 (Fig. 1), which contains a long-range RNA-RNA interaction (nts 270 141-167 base paired with nts 363-335) was equivalent to the base pairing (nts 141-170 paired 271 with nts 363-332) predicted by Guan et al. (Guan et al., 2012), with the exception of nts 332-334, 272 which are unpaired in the Guan model but are part of the SL5C stem in the SHAPE-informed 273 model (Fig. 1A). SL5A (nts 171-225) was identical to the stem-loop designated as SLIV 274 previously (Brown et al., 2007; Guan et al., 2011). Furthermore, SL5A is remarkably similar to a 275 stem-loop, predicted and designated SL5 by Chen et al. (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010) based upon 276 a structural-phylogenetic analysis of the 5'UTRs of betacoronaviruses. SHAPE analysis has also 277 provided biochemical support for SL5B, SL5C, SL6 and SL7, which, in MHV, previously lacked 278 support from genetic or biochemical studies. 279 Previously, the Brian lab defined four stem loops, SLI, II, III and IV, within the 210 nts 280 5'UTR of BCoV using the Mfold algorithm and their existence is supported by enzymatic 281 probing and mutational analysis in DI RNA replication assays (Chang et al., 1994; Raman et al., 282 2003; Raman and Brian, 2005). It should be noted that the four stem loops defined by the Brian 283 lab differ from the structures predicted by our group, except that SLIII in the Brian model is 284 almost identical with the predicted SL4b in MHV (Kang et al., 2006a). 285 Fig. 1 shows a comparison of the secondary structure of MHV-A59 informed by SHAPE 286 analysis (Fig. 1A) with the most thermodynamically stable models of the 5' most 474 nts of 287BCoV-Mebus(Fig. 1B), SARS-CoV(Fig. 1D), and MERS-CoV(Fig. 1C), generated by 288RNAstructure software without incorporating any SHAPE reactivity data. In general, the overall 289 configuration of the three models is similar despite the relatively high divergence of the 290 nucleotide sequence. A core feature is a conserved SL5ABC four-helix junction, a finding 291 strongly consistent with a conserved core architecture(Laing and Schlick, 2009). The initiation 292 codon for nsp1 is in a similar position in SL5A in the two lineage A beta-CoVs, MHV and 293 BCoV, whereas the initiation codon for SARS-CoV (lineage B) nsp1 and MERS-CoV (lineage 294 C) are in more 3' positions, in the first part of the 3' side of S5 for SARS-CoV and in SL5B for 295 MERS-CoV, as shown in Fig.1. All four models contain the long-range base-pairing between 296 5'UTR sequences and the nsp1 coding region that make up the S5 stem. The lengths of 297 connecting single-stranded junctions between the helices are also generally similar or identical, 298 although the single stranded junctions between SL5A and the other two helices (S5 and SL5B, 299 see Fig. 1) are shorter for BCoV than they are in MHV or SARS-CoV. The majority of the 300 RNAstructure-based model for BCoV-Mebus (Fig. 1B) is in good agreement with the model for 301 the 5'UTR and N-terminal nsp1 coding region of BCoV generated by Mfold modeling, 302 phylogenetic covariation, and biochemical and genetic studies (Brown et al., 2007; Chen and 303 Olsthoorn, 2010; Guan et al., 2012; Guan et al., 2011; Kang et al., 2006a; Liu et al., 2007; 304 Raman et al., 2003; Raman and Brian, 2005), although the nomenclature is not equivalent. Parts 305 of the RNAstructure-based model for SARS-CoV (Fig. 1D) are also similar to the model for the 306 5' proximal sequence of SARS-CoV developed through structural-phylogenetic analysis, 307 especially the presence of the substructures, SL5A, 5B and 5C which have been proposed to 308 function in genome packaging (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010). Following the S5 helical stem, the 309 structures generated by RNAstructure are more divergent amongst the four viruses with MHV-310 A59 and BCoV-Mebus being relatively similar, although SL6 and SL7 are predicted to be in a 311 forked stem-loop structure for BCoV whereas for MHV they form separate stem loops, and for 312 SARS-CoV, three stem-loops, SL6, SL7 and SL8, are predicted. In MERS-CoV this region is 313 predicted to fold into two bulged stem-loop structures, although their structure and position 314 differs from that of MHV. 315 SHAPE analysis for in vitro transcribed and refolded RNA and ex virio genomic RNA in 316 the 5' cis-acting region generated identical secondary structures (Yang et al., 2015) and was 317 generally consistent with previous studies of RNA secondary structure in this region. This gives 318 us confidence that this methodology will be useful to explore the fine and long range secondary 319 structures in the context of genomic RNA from authentic viral particles, particularly to determine 320 the interactions of the intergenic regions and their flanking sequences which are likely to play a 321 role in regulating template switching in MHV sgRNA synthesis. 322 The four betacoronavirus RNAstructure-based models described above share the 323 conserved SL1, SL2, SL4 and SL5ABC secondary structure elements with the sequence 324 covariation-based models of the CoV 5'UTR (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010; Kang et al., 2006a; Liu 325 et al., 2007). This conservation of SL1, SL2, SL4, and SL5ABC amongst the betacoronaviruses 326 and SL1, SL2, and SL4 amongst alpha, beta, and gamma, coronaviruses suggests that these secondary structures serve as common cis-acting signals important in CoVs replication and viral 328 RNA synthesis. Functional analyses of individual structural elements described below suggest 329 that the structural features of SL1, SL2 and SL4 are more important than the precise nucleotide 330 sequences in these stem-loops. However it should be noted that in BCoV and SARS-CoV SL3 331 overlaps TRS-L, which defines the leader-body junction region for discontinuous sgRNA 332 synthesis, while SHAPE analysis indicates that the corresponding region is single-stranded in 333 MHV, consistent with the prediction of Liu et al. (Liu et al., 2007). Thus for this region primary 334 sequence is the functionally important feature. 335 3.2 Functional studies of individual structural elements 336 Although the RNA secondary structure of the 5'UTR of coronaviruses appears to be 337 conserved across at least three genera, functional analyses of the individual stem-loop structures 338 have only been performed on two betacoronaviruses, MHV and BCoV. The individual stem-loop 339 structures contained in the 5'UTRs of related betacoronaviruses are largely interchangeable, with 340 the exception of their TRSs (Kang et al., 2006a). The HCoV-OC43 SL1 can functionally replace 341 the MHV SL1 (Li et al., 2008). SARS-CoV SL1, SL2, and SL4 can separately replace their 342 corresponding MHV counterparts in the MHV genome, however, the MHV chimera is not viable 343 when the entire MHV 5'UTR is replaced by the SARS-CoV 5'UTR even when the MHV leader 344 TRS is substituted for the SARS TRS (Kang et al., 2006a). Replacement of each of four 5' end 345 cis-acting stem-loops, SL1, SL2, SL4 and SL5A in the MHV genome with their counterparts in 346 the BCoV genome yields chimeric viruses with near-wild-type MHV phenotypes. However, the 347 32 nts (nts 142-173, see Fig. 1) which make up the 5' side of S5 in the BCoV 5'UTR and which 348 were predicted to be single-stranded in an earlier thermodynamic and phylogenetic model (Guan 349 et al., 2011), cannot directly replace the equivalent sequences in MHV without genetic adaptation (Guan et al., 2012; Guan et al., 2011). These adaptations suggested that a , Fig. 1 shows the near identity of the location of the initiating AUG for MHV-354 A59 and BCoV-Mebus in SL5A, and the more 3' location for the SARS-CoV initiation codon in 355 the 3' side of S5. An attempt to create an MHV chimeric virus in which the entire MHV 5'UTR 356 was replaced by the SARS-CoV 5'UTR failed, even when the MHV leader TRS was substituted 357 for the SARS-CoV TRS (Kang et al., 2006a). The likely explanation for this failure is the 358 different locations for the initiating AUGs of the two viruses. Thus the replacement of the MHV 359 5'UTR with the SARS-CoV 5'UTR would disrupt the long-range interaction in S5. Similarly, 360 the BCoV 32 nts region (nts 142-173) could not directly replace the corresponding 30 nts 361 sequences in MHV-A59 without genetic adaptation (Guan et al., 2011), which is likely explained 362 by partial disruption of base-pairing in S5, a long-range interaction between this region (nts 142-363 173) and sequences approximately 200 nts downstream within the nsp1 coding sequence in both 364 MHV and BCoV. 365 A new member of the betacoronaviruses, MERS-CoV, is a close relative of bat 366 coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5 (Drexler et al., 2014). Prediction with RNAstructure (Mathews 367 et al., 2004) showed that the most stable secondary structures in the 5' end 350 nts region for 368 MERS-CoV and Bat CoV HKU5-1 are very similar and are also similar to those for MHV, 369

FIGREF6.text: 378 canonical base pairs divide the SL1 helical stem into upper and lower parts. The upper part of 379 SL1 is required to be base-paired for efficient virus replication. Mutations that destroy base 380 pairing of this region are lethal or generate viruses with impaired phenotypes. Compensatory 381 mutations introduced in both sides of the stem that restored the base pairing produce viable 382 viruses with phenotypes similar to wild type virus. In contrast, the viruses containing mutations 383 that destroy base pairing in the lower region of SL1 are viable, and the compensatory mutations 384 predicted to restore base pairing are lethal, suggesting that the sequences rather than base pairing 385 in the lower portion of the SL1 stem are required. Genomes carrying lethal mutations in SL1, fail 386 to direct the synthesis of minus-sense subgenomic RNA implying that this element has a crucial 387 role in this process, possibly related to template switching events during leader-body joining (Li 388 et al., 2008). Deletion of a bulged A35 in the lower portion of the stem increases the thermal 389 stability of the helix. Recovered viruses all contained destabilizing second-site mutations near 390 the A35 deletion, suggesting that structural lability of the lower region of SL1 is important for 391 virus replication. The recovered viruses also contain additional mutations, A29G or A78G in the 392 3'UTR, providing genetic evidence supporting an interaction between the 5' and 3'UTRs, as 393 hypothesized in one model of coronavirus subgenomic mRNA synthesis (Zuniga et al., 2004). A 394 dynamic SL1 model is proposed in which the base of SL1 has an optimized lability required to mediate a physical interaction between the 5'UTR and the 3the most conserved secondary structure in the coronavirus 5'UTR, with a 5 nt long 399 stem capped with a (C/U)UUG(U/C) pentaloop being the single most conserved sequence in the 400 5'UTR (Liu et al., 2007). Replacing U48 with C or A is lethal, but the virus containing a U48G 401 mutation is viable and grows with nearly a WT phenotype. Initial NMR studies of SL2 suggested 402 that the imino proton of U48 in the WT sequence or G48 in a U48G mutant donates a hydrogen 403 bond suggesting that it might stabilize a U-turn like conformation, which is consistent with the 404 genetic results (Liu et al., 2007). However, further NMR study showed that MHV SL2 takes on a 405 structure incompatible with a canonical U48-U49-G50 U-turn loop structure, but better fits with 406 an uYNMG(U)a-like or uCUYG(U)a-like tetraloop structure with U51 flipped out and G50 407 stacked on A52 (Liu et al., 2009a). Furthermore, the structure of the SARS-CoV SL2 has been 408 determined at atomic resolution showing that the SL2 pentaloop is stacked on 5-bp stem and 409 adopts a canonical CUYG tetraloop fold with U51 flipped out of the stack (Lee et al., 2011), 410 making it likely that MHV SL2 has a similar structure. Further mutational studies of the loop 411 demonstrate that any nucleotide replacement at C47, U49 and U51 can function and produce 412 viable mutant viruses, whereas the G at position 50 is required (Liu et al., 2009a; Liu et al., 413 2007). Mutational analysis of the SL2 stem demonstrates that the stem is required for viral 414 viability whereas its nucleotide sequences are not important. RT-PCR analyses of the genomes 415containing lethal mutations in SL2 indicate that SL2 is required for subgenomic RNA synthesis 416(Liu et al., 2007).

FIGREF8.text: RNAs enabled a series of experiments using in vitro transcribed DI RNAs containing a 425 reporter gene under the control of either mutant and wild type TRS sequences to probe the 426 sequence requirements for leader-body joining during subgenomic RNA synthesis (Hiscox et al., 427 1995; Makino et al., 1991; van der Most et al., 1994). These experiments demonstrated that 428 there is a requirement for a minimum degree of sequence similarity between the TRS-L and 429 TRS-B for transcription to proceed. However the relationship between the level of sequence 430 similarity between TRS-L and TRS-B and the transcriptional activity at a TRS was not entirely 431 straight-forward and thus additional factors are thought to play a role. In two elegant mutational 432 studies employing a TGEV reverse genetic system this question was re-investigated in the 433 context of infectious virus (Sola et al., 2005; Zuniga et al., 2004). Extending the region of 434 potential base pairing between TRS-L and the complement of TRS-B to include 4 nts of TRS 5' 435 and 3' flanking sequence allowed Sola et al. to predict the ability of each TRS sequence to 436 promote transcription based on the Gibbs free energy of the base pairing of this region (Sola et 437 al., 2005).

FIGREF9.text: the Brian lab showed a BCoV stem-loop they designated as SLIII mapping at 440 nts 97 through 116 in the BCoV 5'UTR, which must be base-paired for BCoV DI RNA replication(Raman et al., 2003). LaterChen  and Olsthoorn (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010) 442 employed a phylogenetic approach to predict the existence of SL4 downstream of the TRS-L, nts 443 80 through 130 in MHV, which differs primarily from SL4 in the model predicted by 444 Leibowitz/Giedroc group in that the proximal 6 nts at left side (nts 74-79) and right side (nts 445 139-134) of SL4 are base paired (Kang et al., 2006a; Liu et al., 2007). For MHV, SL4 was 446 predicted by the Leibowitz/Giedroc group (Kang et al., 2006a; Liu et al., 2007) to be positioned 447 just 3' to the leader TRS and is the first proposed structural RNA element of the 5' UTR 3' of the 448 leader (Fig. 1A). It is predicted to contain a bipartite stem-loop, SL4a and SL4b, separated by a 449 bulge (Kang et al., 2006a; Liu et al., 2007). SL4b in this model corresponds to SLIII in BCoV 450 5'UTR (Raman et al., 2003). 451 Mutations that disrupt the helix in the SLIII in BCoV 5'UTR (Raman et al., 2003) led to 452 loss of RNA accumulation of mutant DI RNA, whereas compensatory mutations that restore the 453 structure result in some level of RNA accumulation of double mutant DI RNA progeny. The 454 Brian group also tested the functional role in viral replication of a short AUG-initiated intra-455 5'UTR ORF (this is represented by the heavy line in Fig. 1) that is present in BCoV, potentially 456 encoding an eight-amino-acid peptide which is phylogenetically conserved, especially among 457 betacoronaviruses. They reported that the amino acid sequences of the intra-5'UTR ORF are 458 important for BCoV DI RNA accumulation and there is a positive correlation between the 459 maintenance of the short ORF and maximal DI RNA accumulation (Raman et al., 2003). The 460 MHV 5'UTR also contains an eight-amino-acid small ORF in SL4b, identical to that present in 461 the corresponding region of BCoV (Raman et al., 2003). Yang et al. (Yang et al., 2011) 462 performed an extensive mutational analysis of MHV SL4, and as part of that study demonstrated 463 contrary to the finding in BCoV DI RNA replication assays that these elements are necessary to 465 continually passage BCoV DI RNA (Raman et al., 2003; Raman and Brian, 2005), but is 466 consistent with a later study by the Brian group which demonstrated that there is positive 467 selection for the small upstream ORF, but it is not essential for MHV replication in cell culture 468 (Wu et al., 2014). The likely explanation for the conflicting results from DI assays and assays 469 done with similar mutants in the context of a complete viral genome is that by their very nature 470 DI replication assays are competition assays with helper wild type virus and recombinant WT DI 471 RNAs that arise during the experiment. Thus the DI experiments may have detected subtle 472 decreases in relative fitness in the BCoV DI RNA replication that are not detected in straight 473 forward viral replication assays that focus on recovering viable viruses. The mutational study of 474 SL4 by Yang et al. (Yang et al., 2011) also indicates that for SL4b, neither the structure nor the 475 sequence have a critical role in viral replication. The parallel analysis of SL4a was consistent 476 with the Chen phylogenetic based model of SL4 (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010) leaving nts 74-79 477 and 131-139 unpaired. However, deletion of the entire MHV 5'UTR SL4 is lethal and the 478 genome carrying this deletion is defective in directing subgenomic RNA synthesis. A viable 479 mutant in which SL4 was replaced with a sequence unrelated stem-loop supports the hypothesis 480 that SL4 functions in part as a "spacer element" and this spacer function plays an important role 481 in directing subgenomic RNA synthesis during virus replication (Yang et al., 2011). 482

Nucleotides 238-262 and nts 284-486 309 make up a segment of the bulged stem-loop designated SL5B in a SHAPE-generated model 487 (Fig. 1), and correspond to an identical stem-loop structure that was predicted as the basal 488 segment of SLV (nts 238 to 262 and nts 284 to 309) for betacoronavirus by Mfold and by 489 covariation analysis(Brown et al., 2007), and as part of an unnamed stem-loop by a structural-490 phylogenetic analysis of betacoronavirus(Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010). The SHAPE-generated 491 model differs from earlier models in that nts 234 to 237 are base-paired with nts 314 to 310 in 492 the base of SL5B but these nucleotides are not included in SLV(Brown et al., 2007) or the 493 corresponding region in Chen model (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010). Moreover, the structure 494 predicted by SHAPE analysis for nts 263 to 283 in the terminal part of SL5B agrees with that 495 predicted by the Chen model (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010), but is different from the stem-loop 496 predicted for the terminal portion of BCoV SLV by Brown et al. (Brown et al., 2007). BCoV 497 SLV (nts 239 to 310) is also supported by RNase structure probing (Brown et al., 2007). SL5C 498 (nts 315 to 334) is similar to the distal part of SLVI predicted by Brown et al. (Brown et al., 499 2007) and to the corresponding region in the Chen model (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010). BCoV 500 SLVI has been identified as a cis-acting element required for DI RNA replication (Brown et al., 501 2007). In a recent study (Yang et al., 2015), disruption of SL5C by four nucleotide substitutions 502 while maintaining the WT amino acid sequence resulted in viable recombinant viruses with only 503 moderate impairment of virus replication compared to that of the WT virus, suggesting that the 504 cis-acting SL5C is not required for viral replication. This contrasts to the data obtained with a 505 BCoV DI RNA model replicon, where the destruction of the distal helix that corresponds to 506 SL5C resulted in a failure of DI RNA replication (Brown et al., 2007). We have previously 507 found similar discordant results with MHV DI RNAs and recombinant viruses containing 508 identical mutations in their 3' UTRs (Johnson et al., 2005), and subsequently with recombinant 509 MHVs containing SL4b mutations (Yang et al., 2011) when compared with a BCoV DI RNA containing similar mutations(Raman et al., 2003). Currently we reason that the nature of DI 511 replication assays, in which a mutant DI RNA must compete with helper wild type virus and 512 recombinant WT DI RNAs that arise during the experiment, allow DI replication experiments to 513 magnify modest decreases in fitness observed in straight forward viral replication assays that 514 focus on recovering viable viruses, making them much more severe or lethal in DI nts 376 to 446 in MHV-A59 and encodes nsp1 amino acid positions 56 to 79. 518

These mutations are predicted to destabilize the distal stem of SL6. A 525 second mutation, VUSB6, includes substitutions at nts 441-446, CGUGAU→GCAGCA (R78A, 526 D79A), was also not viable. Modeling the effects of these mutations on the secondary structure of SL6, 530 indicates that VUSB5 would destabilize the distal portion of SL6 and VUSB6 is predicted to 531 completely open up the bottom of SL6. Viral and Cellular Proteins Binding to the 5' and/or 3' cis-acting RNA Elements 617In the negative-strand discontinuous RNA synthesis model proposed byZuniga  et al. 618 (Zuniga et al., 2004), viral and/or cellular factors binding to cis-acting RNA elements in the 619 genomic RNA 5'UTR, TRS-L and 3'UTR, might circularize the genome through RNA-RNA, or 620 RNA-protein and protein-protein interactions, and thus produce a topology enabling base pairing 621 between TRS-L and the nascent complementary TRS-Bs during synthesis of minus strand RNA. 622

FIGREF18.text: . The MHV N protein binds with high affinity and specificity to the TRS-L and 629 possesses helix unwinding properties that suggest a role in template switching (Baric et al., 1988; 630 Grossoehme et al., 2009; Keane et al., 2012; Nelson et al., 2000), consistent with the 631 demonstration that the TGEV and SARS N proteins have RNA chaperone activity (Zuniga et al., 632 2007). It has also been suggested that N protein binding to TRS-L favors translation of viral 633 RNAs (Tahara et al., 1998). The N binding site in the leader RNA sequence in MHV is 634 specifically localized to nts 56 to 72 (UAAAUCUAAUCUAAACU), and this interaction plays 635 an important role in the discontinuous RNA transcription unique to Nidoviruses (Baric et al., 636 1988; Grossoehme et al., 2009; Keane et al., 2012; Nelson et al., 2000; Stohlman et al., 1988). N 637 protein contains two structurally independent RNA-binding domains: an N-terminal RNA 638 binding domain (NTD) and a C-terminal dimerization domain (CTD) (Hurst et al., 2010) linked 639 by a Ser/Arg (SR)-rich linker. The N-terminal domain (NTD) of the CoV N protein functions as 640 an RNA chaperone in vitro (Zuniga et al., 2007), binds to the TRS, and the NTD-TRS interaction 641 is critical for efficient sgRNA synthesis in MHV (Grossoehme et al., 2009; Keane et al., 2012). 642

For TGEV PTB was also identified as binding to the genomic 5'UTR using an 661 RNA affinity-mass spectroscopy approach (Galan et al., 2009). Heterogeneous nuclear 662 ribonucleoprotein A1 (hnRNP A1) binds to the complement of the 5'leader sequence (negative-663 strand leader) and to the complement of the TRS-B sequences (Choi et al., 2002; Li et al., 1999; 664 Li et al., 1997). The functional importance of this binding has been controversial, Shen and 665 Masters (Shen and Masters, 2001) tested the role of hnRNP A1 in MHV replication by 666 investigating the ability of MHV to replicate in cells lacking a functional hnRNP A1. (Zust et al., 2008) revealed that a 6 nt insertion between the 681 3'UTR pseudoknot and the S3 helix (see Fig. 2) crippled MHV replication but they identified 682 second site mutations in nsp8 and nsp9 which restored viral replication to near normal levels. 683 Based on this genetic result they suggested a model in which a complex of the nsp8 primase plus 684 the associated proteins nsps 7, 9, and 10 binds to the double hairpin conformation of the 3'UTR 685 just adjacent to S3 to initiate minus strand RNA synthesis. The nascent newly synthesized minus 686 strand RNA would displace the 3' half of the S3 helix and permit the formation of the RNA 687 pseudoknot, also allowing binding of the main replicase complex containing nsp12, the main 688 coronavirus RdRP, nsp13 (helicase), plus the associated RNA modification enzymes nsp 14-16 689 (Bhardwaj et al., 2004; Decroly et al., 2008; Ivanov and Ziebuhr, 2004; Minskaia et al., 2006; 690 Snijder et al., 2003). 691 A number of host proteins have been reported to interact with the 3'UTR. Zuniga et al. (Zuniga 724 et al., 2004) have provided strong support for this model by showing that in TGEV the body TRS 725 sequences upstream of each gene signal template switching to the TRS 5′ leader (TRS-L) and 726 proposed a refinement of the model in which the 3' and 5'UTRs interact through RNA-RNA 727 and/or RNA-protein plus protein-protein interactions to promote circulization of the coronavirus 728 genome to place the elongating minus strand in a favorable topology for leader-body joining. 729 Several candidate RNA-protein interactions have been indentified and proposed to 730 contribute to circulization of the genome. FIGREF22.text: Conclusion and Future Directions 756 A series of studies utilizing consensus covariation modeling, chemical probing, nuclear 757 magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, and SHAPE analysis have identified and characterized 758 individual or small numbers of RNA secondary structures in the cis-acting region containing the 759 MHV 5'UTR and extending into the N-terminal nsp1 coding sequence, TRS, 3'UTR and 760 poly(A) tail and many of the studies have examined their functional roles in viral replication 761 (Chen and Olsthoorn, 2010; Guan et al., 2012; Guan et al., 2011; Kang et al., 2006a; Li et al., 762 structures within the cis-acting sequences in the 5'UTR and 3'UTR, and eventually the entire 764 MHV genome, and of the RNA-RNA(s), RNA-protein(s) interactions that direct viral RNA 765 synthesis and virus replication will assist our understanding of these processes. Understanding 766 these interactions in highly pathogenic coronaviruses, such as SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, may 767 enable the design of small molecule inhibitors of these replicative processes. , K.S., Mizutani, A., Lai, M.M., 2004. TABREF0.text: ). On the other hand, the spike protein 172 is uncleaved in most alphacoronaviruses and the betacoronavirus SARS-CoV. Both E and M are 173 required for normal virion assembly in MHV (Fischer et al., 1998; Maeda et al., 2001), but E 174 protein is not required for assembly for all coronaviruses (DeDiego et al., 2007; Kuo and 175 Masters, 2003). Nucleocapsid protein binds to viral mRNA genome to form the 176 ribonucleoprotein complex and also displays an RNA chaperone activity in vitro (Baric et al., 177 1988; Grossoehme et al., 2009; Masters, 2006; Nelson et al., 2000; Stohlman et al., 1988; Zuniga 178 et al., 2007). This RNA chaperone activity has been proposed to have an important role in 179 genome replication and sgRNA transcription (Zuniga et al., 2007). N proteins contain two 180 structurally independently RNA binding domains, the N-terminal RNA binding domain (NTD) 181 and a C-terminal domain (CTD, residues 256-385) which also has RNA binding activity, joined 182 by a charged linker region rich in serine and arginine residues (SR linker) (Chang et al., 2009; 183 Grossoehme et al., 2009). The NTD makes a specific and high affinity complex with the TRS or 184 its complement (cTRS) and fully unwinds a TRS-cTRS duplex that plays a critical role in 185 subgenomic RNA synthesis and other processes requiring RNA remodeling (Cologna et al., 186 2000; Grossoehme et al., 2009; Hurst et al., 2009; Zuniga et al., 2010). The N3 domain (residues 187 409-454) which extends to the true C-terminus of the N protein plays a role in determining N-188 membrane protein interaction in MHV (Hurst et al., 2005).
